summary:
Carthage, an ancient city in modern-day Tunisia, was a major trading hub in the Mediterranean. Founded by the Phoenicians, it grew into a powerful empire, led by Queen Elissa (or Dido). The city's influence spread across the Southwest Mediterranean.

In 146 BC, Rome destroyed Carthage in the Third Punic War. Later, the Romans rebuilt it as Roman Carthage. Despite its destruction and rebuilding, Carthage remained culturally significant. Today, its ruins are a UNESCO World Heritage Site, offering insights into its past, including debates about the practice of child sacrifice.
title: Carthage
